clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Lay Navigators in Meeting Cancer Patients' Non-Clinical Needs: A Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Project to Better Understand Non-Clinical Needs of Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The Stanford Cancer Center is undertaking a Transformation Initiative in order to improve the quality of care, make it more patient-centered and coordinated across the continuum of care. The newest innovation is to introduce lay navigators to specified high-need patients. The larger goal of the project is to assess whether lay navigators can address non-clinical patient needs in a timely fashion and appropriately connect them with their clinical team when warranted. It is expected that proactive interaction with patients will decrease patient anxiety/stress related to their cancer and facilitate higher patient engagement and improved management of physical, social,and emotional health. For the pilot project, the smaller goal is to understand: how lay navigator time is used; the types and frequency of issues brought up by patients; resources that patients are given or referred to; type and frequency of mode of contact with patients; and patients' acceptance of navigators based on refusal. An electronic intake form will be used to collect this information so that data can be analyzed regularly and informed change can be made to the navigator program as needed

detailed_description.textblock:
The Stanford Cancer Institute is undergoing a 5-year Transformation Initiative that began in 2013. One of the goals of this initiative is to increase patient engagement. The underlying premise is that engaged patients will be more likely to attend all their visits, receive all their treatments, and understand ways to manage treatment side effects so that they are less likely to go to the emergency room (ER) or be admitted to the hospital. An approach being tested is to use lay navigators to help identify patient issues and then help them address the issues through a combination of direct supportive activities (e.g., calling clinical team for the patient) and activities that help the patients help themselves (helping them understand when side effects warrant a call to their clinical team that they make themselves).
Information including patient acceptance/refusal of navigator services; number and types of contacts with patients (phone, in-person, email); types of issues discussed (financial, social, educational, physical, emotional, etc); referrals made; and time spent with patients for each encounter will be routinely entered by the navigators for each patient contact. The data entered will be evaluated regularly to closely monitor navigator activities and better understand cancer patient issues/needs. This information will be used to inform possible training needs of navigators, educational needs of patients,needs for better referral support,help predict navigator case-load, and other issues.
Eligibility Criteria:
All new biopsy positive patients that have a treatment plan or receive surgery, chemotherapy or radiation therapy at Stanford in any of the following cancer care programs (CCP) will be eligible for a navigator: breast, gynecologic oncology, head/neck, gastrointestinal, cutaneous (melanoma patients only), and thoracic. Because there will be more patients eligible than the navigators can manage, only patients with an even MRN will receive a navigator for the pilot. The overall purpose of the pilot is to learn which patients benefit most and which services navigators are able to best help with. The investigators expect the pilot to last 6-12 months. Mixed methods will be used to evaluate the navigators and will include existing patient surveys,missed appointments, unscheduled hospitalizations, ER visits, phone call center volume, time to treatment, increase of percentage of new patients receiving treatment at Stanford, interviews with patients, staff (including navigators), and physicians regarding their experience with and perceived value of navigators

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: There will be six groups in each arm which reflects the six different cancer types.

primary_outcome.description: Frequency of CRMs will be used as a measure to assess quality of information exchange with patients. The hypothesis is that navigated patients will have more complete information about issues such as how to access services, take care of themselves appropriately, and understand symptoms of treatment side effects, which will result in fewer CRMs being generated. CRMs are created when a patient calls into the generic Stanford call line and the person answering is not able to resolve the patient's question. An electronic message is then created which is sent to a pool of nurses specific to a CCP. Someone from the pool then resolves the patient's question.

Responses from apriori selected questions from the transformation evaluation surveys will be evaluated for change over time in navigated patients compared to non-navigated. These results will also be put in the context of insights gained from patient interviews related to quality of care contributed by the navigators.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rates (percentages) of missed and cancelled visits for desired services
secondary_outcome.description: Each of the above 'desired services' will be categorized as 'attended', 'missed,' or 'cancelled.' Rates and percentages of missed, cancelled, unplanned hospitalizations and ER visits will be compared between navigated and non-navigated patients. Unadjusted and adjusted analyses will be conducted. Adjusted analyses will control for patient demographics, clinical characteristics and treating physician.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rates (percentage) of unplanned hospitalization and ER visits
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of rates of unplanned hospitalizations and ER visits among eligible patients in the navigated group vs. un-navigated patients.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from new patient visit (NPV) to first treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of time from new patient visit to first treatment among eligible patients in the navigated group vs. un-navigated patients.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from surgery to chemotherapy or radiation therapy if all treatment modalities are received at Stanford.
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of time from surgery to chemotherapy or radiation therapy among eligible patients in the navigated group vs. un-navigated patients.

secondary_outcome.measure: Retention of patients (ie, increase rates of treatment at Stanford)
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of rates of eligible patients that receive one or more treatments at Stanford in the navigated group vs. un-navigated patients.

intervention.description: Patients who are assigned to intervention will be contacted by a navigator who will explain and offer their services to the patient. Navigators focus efforts on supporting patients in self-management and in supporting non-medical needs.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- New patient to eligible Cancer Care Program (CCP)
- Biopsy positive
- Plan to receive at least one treatment modality at Stanford: surgery, chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy
- Cancer that is treated by any of the following CCPs: Breast, Gynecologic oncology, Head/neck, Cutaneous (melanoma only), Thoracic, Gastrointestinal
- Patient has even numbered MRN
Exclusion Criteria:
- Anyone with odd numbered MRN
- Anyone in other cancer programs that are not included
- Biopsy negative
- No treatment modality received
- Patients with already established care/treatment i.e. not new patients

O'Cathain A, Murphy E, Nicholl J. Three techniques for integrating data in mixed methods studies. BMJ. 2010 Sep 17;341:c4587. doi: 10.1136/bmj.c4587.

Proctor E, Silmere H, Raghavan R, Hovmand P, Aarons G, Bunger A, Griffey R, Hensley M. Outcomes for implementation research: conceptual distinctions, measurement challenges, and research agenda. Adm Policy Ment Health. 2011 Mar;38(2):65-76. doi: 10.1007/s10488-010-0319-7.
